title: RAPID: Multi-Hazard Damage to Puerto Rico’s Infrastructure - Investigation of the Interaction of Hurricane and Earthquakes

hazmapperMaps.name: Multi-Hazard Damage to Puerto Rico’s Infrastructure - Investigation of the Interaction of Hurricane and Earthquakes
hazmapperMaps.hazmapper_name: Multi-Hazard Damage to Puerto Rico Infrastructure - Investigation of the Interaction of Hurricane and Earthquakes
hazmapperMaps.hazmapper_description: This project aims to identify the compounding impacts of 2017 Hurricane Maria and the 2020 Earthquake series. Traditionally, post-disaster damage assessment activities focus on one hazard and overlook the potentially destructive cascading effects of multiple hazards on structures and infrastructure. This project provides data resulting from field reconnaissance emphasizing multi-hazard effects and interactions. The data set includes geotagged pictures, Lidar scans, 360 degree videos and images, UAS videos and images from a first wave of field investigation. Infrastructure surveyed includes port facilities, buildings (particularly historical structures), and bridge infrastructure. This data can be used to understand how the impacts of Hurricane Maria, along with infrastructure aging and delayed recovery or repair activities, may have influenced the damage level and failure modes observed during the earthquake sequence.

title: Infrastructure Resilience and Impact Study for Wildfire-affected Infrastructure in Los Angeles

hazmapperMaps.name: Los Angeles Fires
hazmapperMaps.hazmapper_description: Reconnaissance data of the 2025 Los Angeles fires.

hazmapperMaps.name: PRJ-5857 GEER - 2025 Los Angeles Wildfires
hazmapperMaps.hazmapper_description:
The Palisades and Eaton Fires started on January 7th, 2025 during a major Santa Ana wind storm and burned a total of 15,163 hectares of land until they were fully-contained on January 31st, 2025. Both fires ignited near the wildland-urban interface and spread quickly because of the heavy winds and low humidity, ultimately developing into two of the most devastating conflagrations in California history. The fires caused the deaths of 30 people and combustion of 16,251 structures. 
This dataset was gathered during extensive reconnaissance efforts that started shortly after the fires were contained and field teams could be deployed, and is documented in a GEEER report (Akin et al. 2025) accessible through the following URL: https://doi.org/10.18118/G6X37N. The dataset currently consists of photos, track logs, and shapefiles representing drone flight coverage areas. The dataset will likely be amended in the future to include LiDAR point clouds, shapefiles representing aerial LiDAR flight paths, and observations of any future land movements.
The data presented in this report will support future studies of infrastructure system performance and research aimed at developing improved post-wildfire hydrology and sediment movement models. As such, these efforts follow in GEER’s long tradition of turning disaster into knowledge.
